A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.

An element $v \in R$ is called a least common multiple of $x_{1}, \ldots, x_{n} \in R$ if: (i) $x_{i} \mid v$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, i.e., $v$ is a common multiple of all the $x_{i}$. (ii) If $a \in R$ is a common multiple of the $x_{i}$, i.e., if $x_{i} \mid a$ for $i=1, \ldots, n$, then $v \mid a$.
Does the concept of a/an Ring Isomorphism need to be defined for a definition of a/an Least common multiple to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a least common multiple (LCM) in a ring involves finding an element within the ring that satisfies certain divisibility conditions relative to other elements of the same ring. Specifically, an element v is an LCM of elements x1, ..., xn if it is a common multiple of all these elements and any other common multiple of these elements is also a multiple of v. This definition is self-contained within the structure of a single ring and does not inherently require any consideration of another ring or the mappings between rings.

On the other hand, a ring isomorphism involves a bijective homomorphism between two rings, ensuring that the structure and operations of one ring correspond exactly to those of another ring. This concept is crucial when discussing the equivalence of ring structures or transferring properties from one ring to another, but it does not directly influence the internal properties of a single ring such as the existence or determination of an LCM within that ring.

Therefore, the definition and understanding of an LCM within a ring do not depend on the concept of ring isomorphism. The existence and properties of an LCM can be fully analyzed and understood without reference to another ring or a mapping between rings, such as an isomorphism.
